Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Bio-Grid Initiatives for Interdisciplinary Research and Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project continues the Bio-Grid REU Site offering undergraduate students to participate in the research activities associated with the Bio-Grid initiatives conducted at the University of Connecticut. The initiative will advance the application of modern computing infrastructures and information technology to research and practice in various life-science disciplines. Specific research activities include several collaborative projects led by researchers at UConn. A campus-wide computational and data Grid is configured to support the collaborative projects and is available for use by summer students. Training seminars by the project staff will introduce to students concepts about modern grid computing infrastructure and related information technology, as well as some ongoing life-science research projects currently being grid-enabled. Joint seminars with all UConn REU Sites on research ethics and research diversity are designed for students. Participants will have the opportunity to participate in the International Bio-Grid Workshop, hosted annually by the PI.

This REU work, as part of a collaborative action with REU site 1156859, will recruit a diverse group of undergraduate students to engage in research that will broaden their interest in academic careers and professions and help develop a globally competitive engineering workforce equipped with innovative cyber-aquatic technologies. Through integrated research, education and outreach programs, this REU site will better prepare these undergraduate participants for future careers in academia or industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award (OCI-1156837) was funded for fifteen students during a three-year period (2012-2014). Per discussions with program officers, the Bio-Grid REU program supported six undergrad students for ten weeks from May 20, 2012 to July 27, 2012; and nine undergrad students for ten weeks from May 27, 2013 to Aug. 2, 2013. There was no program in the summer of 2015.

Technical seminars in the ?rst week of program invited mentors to give a research presentation. This provided sufficient project and mentor information to students before the project assignment at the end of the ?rst week. Departmental seminars on the graduate school application process, research proposal writing targeting the NSF graduate fellowship application, technical report writing and effective scienti?c presentation have also been very well received. Weekly group meetings with the project staff helped resolve any potential problems in a timely manner. Joint REU seminars were integral to our program. The joint workshop on research ethics covered such topics as (1) The Basis of Research Ethics (2) Scienti?c Record Keeping, (3) Ethics in the Use of Humans in Research, (4) Ethics in the Use of Animals in Research, (5) Con?ict of Interest, (6) Ethics in Mentoring and Training Relationship, (7) Misconduct of Research, (8) Ethics in Publication and Authorship, and (9) Case Studies. The informational session on graduate research fellowship application introduced to students the various fellowship opportunities, targeting especially at the NSF graduate research fellowship program.

The mid-term Bio-Grid mini-Symposium required all Bio-Grid students to prepare a 15-min or so oral presentation, accompanied by a one-page research summary. The minisymposium was designed to get students familiar with the "proposal defense" stage when in graduate school. It also equipped students with knowledge about grant proposal writing. The ?nal Bio-Grid Symposium program was the culminating event. Each project was alloted 30-min for an oral presentation. A technical report was due before students left the program.

Research projects for summer students were designed from ongoing research projects by faculty members. Summer students worked closely with their faculty, graduate students and other mentors.

We recruited 6 students in the summer of 2012, including Briere, Emily (Duke University, Mechanical Engineering); Dhanaraj, Dhinakaran (University of Connecticut, Electrical and Computer Engineering);  Espinoza, Max (Fairfield University, Computer Science);  Hocum, Jonah (Lewis-Clark State College, Computer Science); Knowlton, Stephanie (University of Connecticut, Biomedical Engineering); and Mulhall, Brian (University of Connecticut, Computer Science and Engineering). 

In the subsequent summer of 2013 we recruited 9 students, including Busch, Rachel (University of Massachusetts Amherst, Computer Science); DeLuccia, Luke (Hobart College, Computer Science);  Felekey, Edward (University of Connecticut, Computer Science and Engineering);  Mauthe, Jacob (University of Maine-Orono, Microbiology); McDonald, Aidan (University of Puget Sound, Computer Science); Mohan, Sominder (Swarthmore College, Computer Science & Electronic Systems Design); Penrod, Erin (University of Tennessee at Chattanooga, Computer Science); Petersen, Andrew (Loyola Marymount University, Electrical Engineering); and Van Pelt, Samuel (Colorado Mesa University, Computer Science). 

Ae per survey conducted in May 2017, the following students are currently pursuing a graduate degree: Briere, Emily (Stanford, MS); Deluccia, Luke (UPenn, MSE); Espinoza, Max (RPI, PhD); Knowlton, Stephanie (UConn, PhD);  and Petersen, Andrew (USC, PhD).

Stephanie Knowlton won an NSF Graduate Research Fellowship in 2016.

Luke, Andrew and Sominder have had their summer research work successfully published in the following journal articles:

* NT Tran, L DeLuccia, A McDonald and C-H Huang, “Cross-Disciplinary Detection and Analysis of Network Motifs“, Bioinformatics and Biology Insights, 2015:9, pp. 49-60. (PMID: 25983553)

* NT Tran, S Mohan, Z Xu and CH Huang, “Current Innovations and Future Challenges of Network Motif Detection”, Briefings in Bioinformatics, Vol 16, No 3, 2015, pp. 497-525. (PMID: 24966356)
